TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the senators who participated in this debate: Senator Collins, Senator Woodley, Senator Macdonald, Senator Margetts, Senator Calvert, Senator Crane and Senator Panizza. Two or three of those people are eminent wool growers themselves, and I am sure they gave their pecuniary interests.

SPEECH.PARA: To those individuals in the wool industry who generously gave their time to provide information to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, I thank them very much. It should be placed on the record that the federal government is well aware of the crisis which is currently facing the wool industry. A day rarely goes by without some member of the community raising the plight of the wool industry with my officers. The government, through the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Anderson, and I will continue to examine the options which will alleviate and overcome the current crisis in the industry.

While the current prices remain below the cost of production for the majority of producers, there are indications which would suggest that prices will increase further in the near future. Pipeline stocks are currently at very low levels, and it has been predicted by the IWS that demand and prices are likely to increase. It would be great if that were to happen. Consistent price increases for final wool since the beginning of the year would suggest that there are many areas that may give price relief in the near future for the higher micron categories of the market.

The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 currently before the parliament is a package covering three key areas: offshore mining licences, poultry industry administrative arrangements and wool industry issues. These are all very important industries for Australia. The wool industry provisions have attracted motions of amendment, and many of the issues raised are covered in the second reading speech. Nonetheless, I would like to add a few of the following comments.

I again thank Senator Collins for his contribution. Industry can draw some solace from the fact that this bill has received the full support of the Australian Labor Party and the coalition government. However, it must be said that I am surprised and disappointed by Senator Woodley's comments in this debate. Many of his comments demonstrate a complete naivety and lack of understanding of the magnitude of the problems currently confronting the wool industry.

Senator Woodley stated that the amendments proposed in this bill had been described by the government as being the `panacea' to the problems of the wool industry. At no stage did the minister or any representative of this government make such a ridiculous statement. The problems which currently beset the industry are of an enormous proportion. As Senator Collins noted, how easy it would be if the problems of the wool industry could be simply solved by changes to Wool International.

Senator Woodley' statements of this nature do nothing to assist this beleaguered industry. They only serve to demonstrate the naivety and complete ignorance of the Democrats and their inability to address problems of national importance. Yet Senator Woodley went further. He again attacked Wool International for their failure to appear before the Senate legislative committee. As had already been noted on a number of different occasions by a number of different members, Wool International provided a written submission to the committee and officers of Wool International were also present at the first night of hearings. Not at any stage during the hearings did Senator Woodley call for Wool International to provide evidence, yet he persists in denigrating this organisation for their failure to appear. I and many other members of this chamber keenly await to hear Senator Woodley's explanation for his continued denigration of Wool International.

BREAK.PARA: The amendments moved by Senator Woodley are fundamentally directed towards the independence of Wool International Holdings from Wool International. He is first proposing to do this through specifying clearly how and which directors can be appointed to Wool International Holdings. In principle, we agree that there should be independence of Wool International Holdings in its operations. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has made it clear on several occasions that he will be looking very carefully at the independence issue in any consideration of such a proposal. However, there are significant problems in what Senator Woodley is proposing. It involves government in the process when government is working to withdraw from industry intervention. It also has the effect of applying these conditions to other matters which are not necessarily the subject of the amendment.

I think Senator Woodley would be well aware of the government's record when it was involved in the wool industry. This government will not entertain any ideas of involving itself when, at the May round table discussions, it was quite clear that the industry wanted to be master of its own destiny and its own dynasty. Senator Woodley now wants to drag the government back into it. I have sat on committees with Senator Woodley, and I cannot understand his reasoning for that.

Senator Woodley's amendment also provides for funding of the Wool International Holdings program to be by way of an interest‐free loan. As I understand it, this is aimed at ensuring that ultimate ownership of the $24 million is in the hands of wool growers. The wool industry generally accepted the provision that the section 51 funds, which are to be used to fund the Wool International Holdings program, would be available as seed capital for development work by Wool International. This is contrary to Senator Woodley's proposed amendment.

The amendments to be moved by Senator Woodley are reflected in his dissenting report contained in the report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on its consideration of this bill. The Senate committee recommended the bill be agreed to without amendment. No member dissented from that report except Senator Woodley. Senator Woodley, I sincerely hope that the lack of understanding and ignorance which has been demonstrated by your arguments in relation to this important bill do not come to characterise the Democrats' performance on other nationally important pieces of legislation.

Senator Woodley also raised a number of questions concerning the Australian Animal Health Council, the AAHC. Senator Woodley asked: what contributions do other parties make? Other contributing parties are the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, the Pork Council of Australia, the Australian Chicken Meat Federation, the Australian Egg Industry Association, the Australian Horse Council, all state and territory governments, and the Commonwealth government. Funding contributions are on the basis of one-third each—Commonwealth, states/territories and industry—with funding of non-industry involved.

Senator Woodley also asked: what was the role and purpose of the AAHC? The AAHC has the task of ensuring that animal health services in Australia are adequate to ensure Australia can meet to a high standard the requirements of domestic and international markets for livestock products. Finally, Senator Woodley asked whether the AAHC was filling gaps caused by state closures of laboratories. As mentioned in the answer to the previous question, the AAHC is assessing as a matter of urgency the overall adequacy of animal health services on a national basis.

The amendments proposed by Senator Margetts would have the effect of setting the disallowance period after the tabling of an instrument of approval made under the Wool International Act 1993 by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to 15 days. Under parliamentary procedure, that gives a senator 15 sitting days after tabling to give notice of a motion to disallow the instrument. It then gives the Senate a further 15 days to resolve the motion, which must be debated, called on or withdrawn. Potentially there is a total of 30 sitting days. The current session will not have been long enough for that to have happened. There is a precedence in legislation for shorter disallowance periods than the 15 days. I consider the provision in the bill for three days to be reasonable and appropriate. I therefore reject the senator's amendment.

In conclusion, may I just add that should this bill be delayed there would be serious implications for the wool industry, particularly in relation to the wool tax. If the wool tax is not set to zero before 1 July 1996, each wool grower stands to forgo approximately $3,000 in the 1996-97 financial year. In relation to mining licences, all licences currently issued could potentially be challenged should this bill be delayed any further. On the basis of these factors, I reject Senator Woodley's and Senator Margetts's proposed amendments and encourage this chamber to pass the bill without amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

That matter was raised by quite a number of other witnesses. Rather than go through all of those again and list them, I will leave that for members of this chamber to do so at their leisure. But it was clearly stated by the Western Australian Farmers Federation and by others that that is how they would see this subsidiary company of Wool International proceeding.

The Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia also underline the same preference on their part for the way in which Wool International Holdings would operate. I read from their written submission:

I need to explain to the chamber what the question referred to is. This is a ballot which has been published in many of the rural papers and has been put to a number of meetings of wool growers around Australia. The proposal is as follows:

That the Government be asked to legislate to alter the fixed selling schedule of the stockpile immediately in favour of a more commercially flexible selling strategy and that interest and holding costs be met from the sale proceeds.

For the interest of the chamber, a number of meetings have been held and a number of wool growers have voted yes to that proposal. I can place on the record the numbers voting. At the meeting in Wedderburn, 389 wool growers voted yes and 30 wool growers voted no. At the meeting in Jerilderie, 559 wool growers voted yes and 27 wool growers voted no and there were seven informal votes. At Dubbo, 1,298 wool growers voted for change and 59 were against. I simply place those numbers on the record.

Senator Brownhill suggests that I am naive. That may be so, Senator Brownhill, but I have listened to many wool growers in this nation and whether you like it or not I think the evidence is becoming fairly overwhelming that the position taken by the government and the Labor Party in this regard is certainly in question. I think it would behove you to take note of that.

I have to perhaps plead a little naivety in that I did not ask at the second hearing where Wool International was. I was aware that they were present at the first hearing. In many of the conversations I had with people who are members of the Wool Council and members of peak bodies, they pleaded with me, `Do not prevent this legislation going through because it is the only hope we've got.' I was originally concerned that the Senate would be left with a dilemma about its responsibility to Wool International Holdings or any such body in the future making decisions on such things as futures tradings or hedging, and that somehow or other the Senate would be brought into that responsibility. Part of this argument, basically, is that the Senate has to take responsibility for giving Wool International Holdings the greatest ability to make quick decisions so that it can conduct this trading.

We thought that the most logical course to take on these unresolved issues is to remove reference to that ability to involve Wool International Holdings in such trading until those issues are resolved. The Senate should not be held responsible one way or the other for the futures trading or hedging of such an establishment. It should not be the role of government to require people to pay a levy and then allow that levy to be used in such speculation.

We know that there is a growing speculation in the world economy. But we do not believe it is right to require a compulsory levy so that somebody else can use that money to involve themselves in such trading. And that is the basis of these three amendments: instead of holding the Senate responsible for what happens to the disallowance, we are deleting that reference as well as the reference to Wool International Holdings because we do not think such reference is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The government in introducing this legislation is using the catchcry of accountability as a pretext for rolling back 25 years worth of hard‐won improvement in the political status of indigenous people. The number of amendments that we are going to be moving to this bill is not large, however, they do go to the heart of the government's intentions for this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's approach consists of four main proposals: the appointment of the chairperson of ATSIC; empowering the minister to appoint an administrator over ATSIC's affairs; reducing the number of regional councillors; and measures to improve the accountability of ATSIC regional councils. The opposition opposes the first three proposals, but supports the amendments for greater accountability of regional councils with some reservations as to the appropriate means by which this is to be achieved.

There has been a grave lack of proper consultation between the government and Aboriginal people in regard to this bill. The bill was not at any time made available by the government to Mick Dodson, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, who has a statutory duty under his act—and I quote:

. . . to examine enactments and proposed enactments for the purpose of ascertaining whether they recognise and protect the human rights of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders and to report to the minister the results of any such examination.

I stress that the wording of that statute does not relate simply to enactments, that is, actual bills, but also to proposed enactments. I think I speak for the Green and Democrat senators who were present at the Senate committee hearings on Friday—committee hearings that were extremely useful—when I say that, in respect of those matters, we were dismayed by the evidence that Mr Dodson gave to the committee.

By the way, in passing, and purely because Senator Boswell is in the chamber, I say to Senator Boswell that I examined the Hansard record after the committee hearing. With regard to the references that drew attention to the position of an administrator in respect of ATSIC and the Wool Corporation, I assure Senator Boswell that if any offence was caused to you by a very flippant comment that I made on my return to the committee, in respect of comparing Aboriginal people with sheep, I do not suggest, having read the Hansard, that you suggested that at all. I did tell you that I would withdraw that assertion, and I do so now.

I want to talk about the history that is attached to the appointment of the chair, because reference to the Senate Hansard will indicate there is a long history in terms of particular positions that have been taken from time to time by people in the Senate chamber on this very important question and the positions that are being taken now. Reference can be made to things that I said at the time, then representing the government in the Senate, with respect to amendments which we moved to provide the ATSIC board with the power to elect its own spokesperson. I must say I do have a strong position on this.

When ATSIC was first established, it was recognised that it was a unique organisation. It was unique then and it remains unique, six or seven years later. At that time it was felt, being so unique, that it was appropriate to proceed with some caution in providing the government with the assurances that it needed to appoint the chair by the government.

I point out in passing that the chief executive officer of ATSIC, rather than the chair, is the person who is responsible, in a real sense, for the day‐to‐day accountability of ATSIC. The chair, of course, ultimately is responsible for ATSIC and how it performs, but the day‐to‐day accountability of ATSIC is very much in the hands of the chief executive. The chief executive is also appointed by the minister. We are not suggesting that any changes be made to that arrangement. So we are not proposing that the chief executive officer, currently Ms Pat Turner, be appointed by anyone other than the minister. She, or whoever is in that position, arguably would be the person most directly involved in ensuring that ATSIC is properly accountable for the public money that it spends. We have no dispute that that appointment was made by the minister and continues to be made by the minister.

But the chair of ATSIC, it must be said, has a multi‐purpose role. The chief executive is very much responsible for accountability. That would probably constitute the majority, in a real sense, of her job. But the chair of ATSIC has a multitude of responsibilities. Ultimate accountability is only one of them. She is, in a real sense, the political head of the organisation as well—a role that the CEO does not, and cannot, play.It is right and proper that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission should have a chair who can speak, in a real sense, on behalf of Aboriginal Australia. That is one of the reasons why ATSIC was established in the first place—to give it that kind of voice and to give the voice the status that the chair of ATSIC has. I find it impossible at this stage in ATSIC's development to agree to a proposition to continue to appoint the chair of ATSIC in this way. I find it to be absolutely irreconcilable with the role that ATSIC is now expected to play.

Some people thought I was joking when I made what seemed to me, looking at the words, to be a very obvious comparison, in the committee meeting last Friday. I think it was Commissioner Dodson who drew members' attention to the second reading speech by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). Listed in that speech were the attributes that should be held by the chair of ATSIC. I drew attention to the fact that the minister was not quoting his own words in that part of the speech but was simply endorsing the attributes that a chair should have. Listed among them was the ability to behave properly in a public place, to be able to conduct themselves—and I am paraphrasing it, senator, in respect of your outrage—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not outrage.

—But to behave in a responsible manner at major public occasions. Mixing with foreign dignitaries was the term that was used. I said then—and meant it, as I usually do—that I actually believed that that was one of the attributes you would expect and, I might add, from my experience with them, which Aboriginal Australia would also expect from their chair.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe—I am very happy to go on the public record with this—that we can reasonably impose a greater standard in respect of ATSIC than we impose upon ourselves in parliament. After all, the most senior people in our democratic society are the Prime Minister, the head of the federal government, and, respectively, the premiers of the state governments. In other words, they are leaders, just like the head of ATSIC is a leader. I do not think that we can reasonably expect a better standard of behaviour from the head of ATSIC than we can from the heads of government.
It was not, in fact, a flippant point I was making with my obvious comparison to the

Premier of Victoria. The point I was making was this: it is obvious that the Prime Minister of Australia from time to time has to deal with premiers—I am not suggesting the Premier of Victoria is in this boat—he would much rather not be dealing with. I am quite sure that from time to time the Prime Minister of Australia, irrespective of his political persuasion, would probably like, if he had his druthers, to remove a head of a state government that he finds very irritating, combative, unhelpful and so on. But that, of course, is the role in a democratic society that these people are entitled to take.

Therefore, it is not, in my view, open to the government to want to retain the power of appointing the chair of ATSIC because that person, from time to time, might be a person, if they were elected, that the government might find inconvenient or disagreeable. In my view, that is precisely what might happen from time to time in ATSIC, as it happens in respect of the Commonwealth and state leaders around Australia who are democratically elected.

BREAK.PARA: I was only half joking when I asked Commissioner Dodson that question about that major public function attended by international dignitaries. As you know, Senator Herron, there were international dignitaries present from Japan, a country not only important to Australia, but also famous for its protocol. Australian firms spend millions of dollars every year training their executives not to offend the Japanese. That is why I used that example of the head of ATSIC, on a major public occasion in the presence of the same dignitaries, suddenly shovelling sand all over the camera crews that were present. I am not sure what the Japanese word for `idiot' is, but I am sure it got a hell of a workout behind closed doors after that particular event, no matter how much they might have laughed politely at the time.

All I am basically asking is that the same standard be applied to ATSIC as the Commonwealth government would accept has to be applied to political leaders in other organisations, and that is state governments. That is the point that was being made, and I think properly made. I do believe that, if after this length of time ATSIC cannot be trusted to elect its own chief spokesperson—that is really what we are talking about—to put a view on behalf of Aboriginal Australia which may, from time to time, be inconvenient for the government, then it is a pretty sad position that we have reached. That is a major issue as far as I and the opposition are concerned. We disagree with this particular legislation, and we will oppose this measure strongly.

The Australian Democrats, rightly in my view, have had a rethink about it. The reason that that proposal failed on that occasion was that the Democrats were not convinced at that stage, as they now are, that the organisation had now reached that point.

The question of appointing the administrator over ATSIC's affairs has been canvassed at length before, and I will not waste the time of the Senate by going over that now. That was canvassed in the committee and in other places, so I will not go over that again. The reduction in the number of regional councillors is based on an ATSIC report in February 1995 which recommended this reduction in the number of regional councillors and this is the sole basis for the government's decision. The reality is that there are many indigenous people all over Australia who have grave concerns about the effective reduction in the number of regional councillors. The number has already been reduced from 809 to the current 593 following the reduction in the number of regional councils in 1993 from 60 to 36, and no justification has been given for a further reduction either on efficiency grounds or in terms of effective representation.

Can I say to the minister that I do not think that we are diametrically opposed to some consideration being given to a further reduction, but there are clearly concerns about where this might lead to some anomalous situations. I believe that one such situation, from South Australia from memory, was actually given to the committee on Friday. I believe that, whilst at the end of the day I think we may not be too far apart on this issue, there needs to be some additional flexibility to that which the government is currently providing for in this proposal.

So far as the increased accountability for regional councils is concerned, the opposition has said that it will look at constructive amendments to the act, and in terms of these provisions there are some amendments which have merit, and we will not be opposing those amendments. However, we are very concerned that, in a number of cases, the government proposes to remove a non-custodial penalty alternative for certain offences under the act. The reason for our concern is that this stands in direct contravention of recommendation 92 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which was that imprisonment should only be used as a punishment of last resort.

Sadly, Amnesty International has only very recently pointed to the very unpalatable truth that the number of Aboriginal people dying in custody in Australia has actually increased since the royal commission into that matter was completed, and not decreased. This is not the time, particularly at the federal level, for us to be acting in contravention of the recommendations of the commission.

As people with even a scant interest in this matter would know from the media reports on these events, in so many of these cases, the reason for these continuing deaths in custody is simply that state governments, which are in fact responsible for the prison systems around Australia, simply have not implemented the most basic recommendations—even the interim recommendations—of the commission into black deaths in custody. That is a very sad state of affairs. The Labor Party will propose amendments to the bill to ensure that the non-custodial penalty option remains in all of these cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today addressing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill. I would like to begin by commending the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, for introducing a series of amendments which I know he has based on thorough consultation with the wider community—and, in particular, those people with specific Aboriginal interests—and not just on consultation with a few sectional interests that are often focused on so zealously either by the media or by many people in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways, it is a concern to me when issues that so specifically relate to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have to be brought back before this parliament time and time again. Whilst we must always acknowledge the important heritage issues that do apply to the indigenous communities within Australia, it is a concern that so often we are seen to be patronising or paternalistic in many of the endeavours that we undertake in this parliament.

As we have witnessed over the years, consecutive Labor ministers—in the last 13 years, in particular—have ignored the concerns of the broader Aboriginal people, while pandering to the wishes of a select few. This was particularly evident in the period leading up to the introduction of the original ATSIC legislation in 1989. It is now patently obvious that the consultation process then was inadequate and failed to accommodate the views of the vast majority of Aboriginal people. At the time, members of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, a body located across northern Australia, said:
After one year of so called consultation, we tribal people have almost no idea what this new commission is about.
Even the former secretary to the then Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Charles Perkins, claimed the Labor government did not have a mandate from the Aboriginal community.

When this legislation was being debated, I made some extrapolations which, with the benefit of hindsight, have proved to be somewhat prophetic. I refer senators to my speech on the second reading debate for the original ATSIC legislation on 17 August 1989, when I made the observation:

The Bill is deficient structurally and in detailed drafting, and accountability will not be assured. It has already been quite widely indicated that there will be amendments to this legislation—considerable amendments that will take some time to deal with—both from the Opposition and from the Australian Democrats. Sadly it is the Aboriginal people and the general body of Australian taxpayers who will be worst served by ATSIC compared with the existing arrangements.
A separate quote from that speech continued:

Let me draw to a conclusion the issues that I see becoming a problem. ATSIC will fail to meet its objectives because of a failure to achieve a consensus amongst the very people the proposal is designed to assist, Aboriginal Australians. Let us all ask the question: What will life be like under ATSIC? The administrative problems seen in the past will only get worse and Aborigines will cop the blame. Racism will be entrenched institutionally—by, if one can believe it, a Labor Government. The interests of traditional Aboriginal people will be subsumed. There will be a lack of accountability that will be totally confusing if these proposals are adopted.
That, as I mentioned, is an extract of my comments which appeared in the Hansard on 17 August 1989.

PARA.BREAK: In 1993 the Labor government decided to introduce a series of reforms in an attempt to redress some of the more obvious flaws in the initial ATSIC legislation. The Labor govern ment was widely criticised at the time for not consulting with the Aboriginal community. When the bill was tabled, I received representations from many groups—in particular, from the Arltarpilta and Impiyara regional councils in central Australia—which claimed they had not been consulted at all. I assisted these communities by relaying their specific concerns to the former minister for Aboriginal affairs and to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is quite meaningful and coincidental that various Aboriginal leaders from those organisations are here in Canberra at the moment. For the past two days, they have been talking to ATSIC, to departmental officials, to the minister and to others, and they have again been repeating many of their concerns. Yesterday I met with people from the Tea Tree local government community, and they were able to again reinforce and re‐stress their concerns. That is also an important fact in this debate.

As my fellow senators will recall, the coalition, in conjunction with the Australian Democrats, introduced a series of changes to the former Labor government's amendment bill to make ATSIC more accountable and to make the decision on the new chairman more flexible. However, as was acknowledged at the time, the former government's amendment bill did not go far enough to address the problems inherent in the ATSIC legislation. We are now asked to consider a comprehensive series of amendments proposed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, in response to the representations of many Aboriginal people across Australia.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1996 is an important piece of legislation which addresses many of the points Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people have made about ATSIC since it was established. Recent history has shown that the most common criticism of ATSIC is that it needs to be more accountable to the people and the parliament in order to ensure funding is not squandered by the agencies serviced by ATSIC and reaches the Aboriginal people on the ground who need it. The general feeling amongst those who work within or are closely associated with the Aboriginal affairs portfolio is that ATSIC is long overdue for reform or, as one Aboriginal leader suggested, `a well overdue shake‐up'.

The proposal for the commission chairperson to be appointed by the minister represents an important change in ATSIC's structure. In a situation where large amounts of government funds, taxpayers' funds, are expended, it is of fundamental importance that the government maintain a large degree of control.

I welcome Senator Herron's proposal to open regional council meetings and specified documents to the public. This is an important step towards ensuring that ATSIC is transparent and ultimately accountable to its constituency. In the longer term, this will also ensure Aboriginal people have greater access to the decision making process and the option to inspect documentation.

If there was one particular aspect of this legislation to which I am attracted, it is that one. From representations that have been made to me over a long period in politics, I am certainly well aware that the decision making process within Aboriginal communities certainly requires transparency. Aboriginal politics is no different to our own. It is fierce. It is partisan. It is led by particular interest groups, often focusing on particular families and clans. Various aspects of the decision making process not being public, not being open, only leads to accusations—often very false ones—of nepotism and of undue influence and in many respects leads to poor and inadequate decisions with regard to financial decision making that affects many other people in local communities.

I believe that, as long as the rules that are being introduced through this legislation broadly reflect those that apply to local government, we will see a vast improvement in the appropriate governmental ATSIC-type decision making processes that are so fundamentally important. I can think of many examples of where I have had to be involved in electorate representational work to redress the issues that Aboriginal constituents have raised with me when the decision making process has frustrated them or has totally gone against what would be a majority decision in many communities or Aboriginal service delivery organisations.

Likewise, I welcome the proposal dealing specifically with electoral matters. Too often block voting on regional councils freezes out small communities from representation and funding. The amendments will severely limit the avenues available to those who wish to employ unscrupulous means to win office and consequently attempt to control the distribution of ATSIC funds to the detriment of the wider community.

When we look at the history of elections within the various arms and councils of ATSIC and the commission itself and at the very poor turnout in many communities, we see this is not democracy properly working. Not only on an educational level but also as a matter of fairness and equity for many of the Aboriginal people, that electoral matter ought to be properly redressed.

I envisage the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1996 will enjoy an overwhelming degree of support in this chamber. Based on the views that Senator Collins has expressed in the past, I am sure that he will prove to be one of the strongest supporters on the opposition benches. I heard part of Senator Collins's speech today and noted the points he raised. He and I share a constituency in the Northern Territory of which Aboriginal people comprise some 25 per cent, and I know we share many issues from both an electoral perspective and a policy perspective. Earlier I dwelt on my own comments of August 1989, but, interestingly, I would like to quote from Senator Collins's speech of 17 August 1989—and I remind Senator Herron of this:

I have my own personal views about funding for Aboriginal affairs which I have also expressed many times on the public record. My own view about funding for Aboriginal affairs is that the lion's share of that funding should, in fact, be non-discretionary. Bodies such as ATSIC or, indeed, any other bodies that are created should have no discretion to determine how it is spent at all because, in my view, the lion's share of funding for Aboriginal affairs has to be spent directly on improving the desperate living conditions of many of these people who, without doubt, are the most deprived group of people still existing in the Australian community.

It is interesting that Senator Collins often varies from what he said some five or six years ago and today often takes a different stance, for political reasons or a different agenda, in this type of debate. The comments that Senator Collins made in 1989 in relation to the formation of ATSIC are just as relevant and true today as they were when they were said. This bill will result in a more even balance between the ideal of self-determination and, as I said, Senator Collins's preference for non-discretionary funding.

There are many examples of success in areas of Aboriginal affairs and indigenous matters throughout Australia that we should concentrate on. Let me highlight a few. If we look at local government working effectively, then it is with pride that we see in the Northern Territory the great participation of Aboriginal people in the form of local government that applies in most Aboriginal communities, and that is under the Northern Territory local government provisions.

It is the area of community government where municipal functions of various types are transferred and accepted by the local communities and funded through the Northern Territory government schemes. There are many areas of success in the involvement of Aboriginal people in those communities. Many of them are exclusively Aboriginal and many of them are on a shared and participatory basis with wider communities in which the Aboriginal people have a majority say. Certainly there is that change of local government.

I am pleased also to notice that there are many other examples of wider Aboriginal involvement in local government throughout Australia. I welcome and encourage that. I believe that is essential if we are to see the proper participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in all forms and levels of government throughout Australia.

I want to comment on the increasing participation and the role of women within Aboriginal communities. If there is an equal opportunity banner that is working more successfully than anywhere else, it is in the Aboriginal communities, particularly for women aged over 40. As I go into Aboriginal communities I am really pleased to so often note the leadership, the maturity, the control and the influence that Aboriginal women have in community affairs on all the issues, whether it be reflecting social values at a community level or demanding accountability in financial matters. I could highlight many examples of where Aboriginal women's participation outstrips that of their male colleagues in many communities, particularly in the area of responsibility.

If we look at the record of improvement in Aboriginal education at the tertiary level, we see that there are now many fine examples of people electing to be more involved in advancing their own education. We certainly see an improvement in the provision of facilities by the various tertiary institutions throughout Australia.

There are many commercial activities, generally of a joint venture nature, that can highlight the participation, the involvement and the commercial maturity of many Aboriginal communities. That equally stands as a test and a challenge for the maturity and involvement of Aboriginal communities. I am well aware that in the Northern Territory the Traditional Credit Union, which has developed in Arnhem Land as an organisation with banking functions, is an area that has special growth and has the special involvement of Aboriginal people specifically.

Similarly, again in Arnhem Land, there is the demystification of the decision making process. That word is often bandied around these days to mean many things. But it is interesting that the Northern Territory government has involved Aboriginal consultants in the education of police officers, of court officials, of senior administrators and of educationalists in understanding the culture, the language, the processes and the very different reasons by which Aboriginal people make decisions. But it is a reciprocal matter. In Aboriginal communities there are many examples of how the demystification process attempts to explain to and educate Aboriginal people about the reasons, the traditions and the patterns of how we—those of us who come from a European heritage—make decisions and how that applies.

I believe in applying those examples of success—whether it has been in education, women's participation, local or community government, commercial joint ventures or the demystification of decision making—so that we can link these things very carefully to this piece of legislation. This legislation attempts to bring together the decision making processes for Aboriginal people on a basis that gives them hope, opportunity, accountability and acceptability within the broader community.

In conclusion, I would like to express my optimism for the future of Aboriginal affairs under the coalition government and in particular under the leadership of Senator Herron as the minister. By bringing ATSIC more into line with the accountability regime of other Commonwealth departments, the government will ensure that funding reaches Aboriginal people who really need it.

The result of this amendment bill will be a government more responsive to the needs of the broader Aboriginal community. At the same time, we must recognise that so many of these amendments have been sought either because of frustration by inadequate performance or because of the areas of success that need to be specially developed and appropriately brought across to this particular style of legislation. The whole range of provisions and amendments we put forward is very timely.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This will certainly be my last opportunity to deal with the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I hope that when I have left this place others might find it useful to pursue issues raised here because it give us an opportunity to establish where the various elements of the bureaucracy may well have failed and perhaps where they could lift their sights a little. For example, $1.6 million is urgently required under this arrangement for the Office of Film and Literature Classification, according to the Attorney-General's Department.

The explanation is that this is urgent and was erroneously omitted from the appropriation bill as advice was only received by the department on 19 March 1996 that a separate appropriation item would be required. Yet this related to law that was passed last year, as I recall. In order that this expenditure can legally take place under the new item, it is necessary to transfer the appropriation to that item. I guess that is just one of the many examples one keeps seeing of where procedures could be improved. One should not rely on this kind of Advance to the Minister for Finance.

There seems to be an extraordinary number of personal injury matters which require compensation and legal expenses for a whole range of departments. For example, the Defence Department requires $14 million for urgent and unforeseen compensation and legal expenses. The last half a dozen of these Advances to the Minister for Finance have seen a very large number of these matters included. I note that they are lumped together as compensation and legal expenses. I think it would be very useful for the parliament to know which were compensation payments and which were legal expenses, particularly when something like $14 million, in this case, is involved.

Another matter I wanted to raise was a something I questioned with the last Advance to the Minister for Finance relating to the State Electricity Commission of Victoria lodging claims against the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Murray-Darling Rural Water Commission following an accident at the Dartmouth Dam power station in May 1990. The request tabled today says:
Advice from the Principle Solicitor for the Australian Government Solicitor indicated that it was in the best interest of the Commonwealth to agree to contribute $8,500,000 towards the settlement.
At the end of the request, it says:
There may be a need for another request for AMF before the end of the financial year.

I think it is about time parliament was told what is the full cost to this government in having to pick up what appears to be some kind of significant error emerging out of the previous administration. Is it going to be a great deal or not? After all, $8.5 million so far is a very considerable amount by which the government has to stand behind one of its government business enterprises.

I also noticed the Australian Taxation Office requires $2.48 million in compensation and legal expenses. I have already mentioned this in relation to another department. I an wondering why we keep on seeing so many understatements of what is required. For example, current claims on hand of $533,000 and expected expenditure for the remainder of the financial year of $2.65 million seem to suggest a whole range of legal problems with the Australian Taxation Office. I think in previous Advances to the Minister for Finance similar large amounts have been made available.

I am also intrigued to see in the last Advance to the Minister for Finance an extraordinary situation where one department eventually settled and it is going to cost $140,000‐odd in legal costs. I know this is a great problem and hard to forecast, but it does not seem to be being done too well. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Supporting Applications of Issues from the Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to note some of the incidental costs of elections. I notice the Department of Administrative Services requires an extra $5.576 million to cover larger redundancy costs and so on relating to former staff of ministers, office holders and back bench parliamentarians—positions which have been terminated as a result of the election. These payments so far exceed $6 million. I know that the staff would have been concerned about the loss of their jobs. It seems obviously appropriate that there should be proper payment to them for the loss of their jobs. It is one of those hidden costs of a change in government that comes to light in these documents.

I also want to mention another item. The Department of Veterans' Affairs requires a further $1.36 million for the veterans' children education scheme to meet some payments due to the increase in student numbers at both the secondary and tertiary level of education. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to place before the parliament a matter on behalf of Letty Scott, a member of the Aboriginal community who sadly lost her husband in 1985 at Berrimah prison near Darwin in the Northern Territory. However, there is conflicting evidence about the cause of death, and Mrs Scott has asked me to tell the parliament that she strongly believes that her husband was murdered and that she rejects any conclusion that he committed suicide.

PARA.BREAK: Mrs Scott says that there are witnesses who are prepared to come forward under privilege to give new evidence; that there are discrepancies in the original polaroid photographs taken; that some of the evidence given to the royal commission into Aboriginal deaths in custody should be reviewed and retested; that evidence should be sought from other people with knowledge of the circumstances of the death in question; that there is conflicting evidence about the time of death and conflicting evidence about the body temperature, ranging from prison officers stating that the deceased was stone cold through to ambu lance reports stating that his body was still warm.

RE: THE ABORIGINAL PERSON WHO DIED IN CUSTODY AT BERRIMAH PRISON NEAR DARWIN, NORTHERN TERRITORY ON 5 JULY 1985

We have had the instructions of Mrs Letty Scott in connection with matters arising from the death of her husband, while in custody at Berrimah Prison near Darwin, Northern Territory on 5 July 1985. From the material which has been provided to us and which we have reviewed, we have arrived at the view that there are now serious reasons to doubt the outcome and conclusions of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, as regards this matter.

With the view already expressed, it is our submission that this is an appropriate case for the re‐opening of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody to take further evidence and review certain issues and materials previously put before it. For reasons which are outlined below, we believe this is the only appropriate action to take which will serve the interests of justice, the interest of the community including the Aboriginal community and the interests of the family of the deceased.

Because of the nature of the matter and of the continual efforts over many years of Mrs Scott to draw these matters to the attention of authorities, we believe this is not a matter which should now be referred to the Northern Territory Police. Upon the evidence presented to us including the evidence of persons who were in a position to see and to hear certain things, it would appear that, quite contrary to the evidence and the conclusions of the Royal Commission, there was an involvement on the part of four prison officers on the night in question, which has never been the subject of inquiry or evidence.

We would also urge that the names of the witnesses whose statements are referred to in this submission should be protected from disclosure until the holding of the Inquiry sought or until their permission is obtained.

Taken together, the new evidence such as the statements of Messrs Percy and Bindai together with Mrs Scott's account of the differences between the original two polaroid photographs taken by a prison officer on the morning of discovery of the death of the deceased and what purported to be copies of those photographs subsequently shown to her will, in our submission, lead to the need to advance a number of theories and lines of inquiry before a re‐opened Royal Commission which could not otherwise be undertaken without privilege.
In our submission the appointment of an investigator or rapporteur will not be a sufficient response to Mrs Scott's plea for an inquiry and in particular.
(i) Such a person would have no powers of subpoena, power to compel witnesses to answer, and authority to report publicly.
(ii) An adverse report from such an investigator recommending no further action is not likely to satisfy Mrs Scott nor to resolve the issues satisfactorily.
A full judicial inquiry is the only appropriate response for the following reasons:‐
(i) Some of the evidence already given before the RCIADC requires review and further testing.

(ii)_ The new evidence as to photographs, Messrs Percy and Bindai in particular and others whose evidence may not have been sought or if sought, not dealt with appropriately, as apparently in the case of Bindai, must be dealt with properly, with all interested parties having an opportunity to test it.

(iii) Mrs Scott should be given the resources to have some of the existing evidence thoroughly examined and tested by forensic experts. In particular independent forensic pathologists and photographic experts may need to be employed to report and then to give evidence.
(iv) Only a full judicial inquiry will have the necessary authority to deal with and review the findings and methodology of the Royal Commission which preceded it.

(v) Only a further open judicial inquiry will have the authority to settle the issues remaining outstanding to the satisfaction of Mrs Scott, and the wider community of people whose anxiety and doubts about the RCIADS findings would otherwise fester and undermine public confidence in its findings.

This letter and the submission are confidential at this time. However, you will appreciate that Mrs Scott is under media pressure. We would seek a positive and speedy response. If you consider it helpful to receive a delegation we would be pleased to attend upon you or one of your Ministers with counsel retained to assist with the preparation of the submission, Messrs Maurice Neil, Q.C. and Mr Daniel Brezniak of the Sydney Bar.

ISSUES FOR CONSIDERATION
The Death in Custody of an Aboriginal person who died 5 July 1985 at Berrimah Prison, Darwin

The issues which are raised below arise from a consideration of statements; evidence; Coronial report of Cavitt, S.M. and McGregor, S.M. and statements, evidence, transcripts and the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody (RCIADC).

Items 1—5 deal with issues, controversy and apparent contradictions arising from evidence given to the Coronial Inquiry (CI) and/or the RCIADC; Items 6—9 deal with material not put before the RCIADC and Item 10 raises further matters and issues for inquiry.
In support of the matters referred to in this submission, the following documents are attached:‐
1. copy statement of Letty Scott dated 13 August 1993 (regarding viewing of polaroid photographs)
2. copy statement of Letty Scott dated 5 July 1995 (regarding viewing of copy polaroids and police photographs)
3. copy letter from Robert Cavanagh to Rodney Lewis dated 11 April 1995
1. Time of Death—conflicting evidence of body temperature
1.1 Prison Officer (PO) BOWDEN spoke to SCOTT at 4.00 a.m. He was the only one to look into the cell on that occasion (RCIADC) transcript P266)
1.2 PO ROBERTSON described SCOTT—"He was stone cold" and later that "the body was cold to touch" (RCIADC transcript P267 and P290).
1.3 PO BIRBECK said he "found the body cold and wet" (RCIADC transcript P556).
1.4 SGT STEVENS found "the body was coolish" (RCIADC transcript P661‐2)

1.5 DR LEE, forensic pathologist found "the body warm to the touch" (RCIADC transcript P742). DR LEE also had an explanation for the description of "cold, clammy" at P782 and dealt with the meaning of evidence concerning a warm body at P802.
1.6 The St John Ambulance Northern Territory Officers report indicates "patient still warm, no obvious signs of rigor mortis"
Issues:

A. DR Lee pointed out at P802 RCIADC transcript that the information which is conveyed by the statement that "the body is warm to touch" is that this is a body which has not been dead for a long period of time. It is an estimate of the time of death but not a good one. There are however other conflicting assessments of temperature of the body which give rise to an element of doubt on the issue of the time of death.

B. Detective SGT STEVENS gave evidence at the Coronial Inquest that at paragraph 5 of his report he said "DR LEE examined the deceased and estimated that the deceased died within the previous 4 hours from when he examined him at 8.30am".
2. How did the hanging take place?
2.1 In his findings of 16 September 1987 Mr McGREGOR SM indicated that there was "a grill in the ceiling, accessible from bed or stool, . . . a great temptation which could be removed" (22 2926).
2.2 PO ROBERTSON observed in his evidence that there was "a foot stool under the bench" (RCIADC at P268).

2.3 The Royal Commissioner Mr Elliott Johnston QC (RC JOHNSTON) found that "the furniture in the cell is fixed and an examination of the cell, including the demonstration, showed that it would be quite possible for the person of the height of the deceased to stand upon the table and tie one end of a sheet to the ventilation grill. The noose could have been tied earlier or could then have been tied. It would then be a matter of stepping off the table. Death would follow very quickly. Once suspended there was no object that could be reached with hands or feet." (RCIADC transcript P20).

2.4 RC JOHNSTON and further at P67 to say "the Coroner, however, did go rather more widely. He pointed out that the grill in the ceiling, allied with the fact that it could be reached by standing on the table or bed constituted a temptation to a prisoner feeling an urge to inflict harm. . . ".
2.5 The Coroner made a presumption at page 23 of the transcript as follows:
"I presume, it could be reached by standing on the bed or any other furniture in the cell?"

2.6 Acting Senior PO G B WOOD "they do get issued with plastic stools within the cell blocks. They have got a writing desk in one corner, beside the concrete bed. You can reach it from one of the stools".

2.7 A perusal of one of the photographs purporting to be a copy of the polaroid photograph taken by PO BIRBECK which shows the deceased from the rear discloses what appears to be the top of the stool in the foreground next to the bed. The perusal of another of the police photographs shows the stool at the end of and to the side of the bed upon which the deceased was laid out. DR LEE viewed the polaroid photographs at the prison on the day of death and became aware from the original polaroid photograph that the stool was not in a position to be used by the deceased. Nevertheless in his post mortem report (P1 paragraph 3) DR LEE states "the ceiling height is 266cm and the height of the stool that he was standing on was 44cm".
2.8 In his statement to the RCIADC DR LEE said "Although I did not measure the height of the bed the photos show that it was about 30cms and could have been used".

2.9 A perusal of the photograph of the interior of the cell with the deceased layed out on the bed appears to indicate an equivalent height of stool to bed. DR LEE said in his statement to the RCIADC "there is not a lot of difference between the bed and the stool" (P2).
2.10 DET SGT STEVENS says "I saw DR LEE taking measurements of the body, of the distance from the ceiling to the floor and the height of the foot stool (sic).
Issues:
A. The bed was measured on a recent visit and inspection of the cell in Darwin at 27cms. There is therefor a difference between bed and stool of about 17cms.

B From the copy of what purports to be a photographic enlargement of the polaroid photo depicting the hanging body and stool there must be serious doubts the stool could have been, or indeed was used, by the deceased.

C. If, as RC JOHNSTON found, the deceased stepped from the table, there is a high probability the length of sheet connecting the grill to his neck would have been drawn as taut or tightly as possible before stepping from the table, thus undoubtedly leaving his head much closer to the ceiling than the photographs demonstrate.

D. The statement of RC JOHNSTON that "once suspended there was no object that could be reached with hands or feet" appears on the face of it, incorrect. The bed was immediately adjacent and the deceased appears from the relevant photograph to be capable of easily touching the floor with his feet.
3. The presence/absence of blood
3.1 PO ROBERTSON stated that "there was no blood" (RCIADC transcript P267).
3.2 DGT STG STEVENS said that "that he found no signs of blood" (RCIADC transcript P653).
3.3 In his statement of 6 March 1989 Mr LAURIE PERCY in the course of cleaning up the cell afterwards said "he saw blood on the pillow".
Issues:

A. There is a conflict of evidence on the record of the RCIADC which appears to have escaped notice. The reference to blood by Mr Percy was apparently overlooked and should have been further investigated. He was not asked to give evidence to the Commission. His recent statement (see later) makes this aspect of the matter of the utmost importance.
4. What the photographs show
4.1 Deceased is shown in the photograph taken from the rear while hanging in a light colour T-shirt with a pair of shorts torn on the left side.
4.2 The deceased is shown hanging by the neck with a large knot made in a sheet possibly of the same pattern as the sheet shown covering the bed depicted in the same photo.
4.3 A further examination of the photographs especially of the deceased lying prone full length on the bed appears to indicate a pattern of trains, boats and planes on the sheets.

4.4 An examination of the photograph which is a close up representation of the neck of the deceased appears to indicate discolouration and markings on the right side of the neck but which are substantially obscured by the lighting or the manner in which or the aspect from which the photograph was taken. That photograph is taken of the deceased without clothing on the upper torso, apparently at the morgue by Constable Niemann, police photographer.

4.5 A further photograph taken of the left side of the neck and chin below the left ear with the deceased apparently still clothed in a T-shirt shows markings under the left side of the neck at the jaw. No apparent markings on the throat.

4.6 Another photograph which shows the full face of the deceased with no T-shirt showing around the throat but with the sheet loosely hanging around the shoulders of the deceased appears to show a discolouration or marking on the left hand side the throat just about the Adams Apple.
4.7 A further close up photograph taken of the deceased without sheet or upper torso clothing or T-shirt does not show any such apparent markings.
4.8 The photograph of the deceased hanging shows his feet touching or almost touching the floor.
Issues:

A. Dr Lee, the Northern Territory Forensic pathologist at that time, makes reference to "wide band marks". . . "poorly defined" (RCIADC at p.762) some of which are evident from the photographs, in his statement. What seems to be apparent from a close inspection of the photograph referred to in 4.4 requires, in our submission, a much closer examination, perhaps by scientific means to enhance the image.
5. Who took the body down and how?

5.1 PO ROBERTSON states in his evidence to the RCIADC that "I tried to cut the sheet with the scissors which did not work. LAWSON and I then took the weight off the body and I think Mr BOWDEN climbed on the stool to undo the knot at the bed. . . Once the knot was undone we layed him on the bed with the sheet which he had loosened still around his neck".
5.2 PO BIRBECK said that "we cut it away" (the ligature) at P548 of the RCIADC transcript.
Issues:
A. There is a clear and important difference in the evidence of these officers, which needs to he further tested and analysed.
6. The Question of the Photographs

6.1 During March of 1989 in about the first week of the Royal Commission Inquiry into the death of the deceased a meeting was held, attended by staff of the Royal Commission and members of the family of the deceased.

6.2 The meeting took place at the Darwin Magistrates Court Building on the Corner of Nicholls Place and Bennett Street in Darwin. The meeting was attended by Geoffrey Barbaro, solicitor assisting the Royal Commissioner, Mick Dodson, counsel assisting the Royal Commissioner and Letty Scott, Diana Cavanagh and Michelle Mosley. These persons Scott, Cavanagh and Mosley are the immediate family of the deceased. Letty is his widow and Diana and Michelle his daughters. At the meeting the immediate family were shown two polaroid photographs being photographs showing the deceased hanging in his cell. The specific features of the photographs according to the clear recollection of Scott, Cavanagh and Mosley are as follows:
6.2.1 The deceased was hanging by a plain sheet.
6.2.2 The sheet which was around the neck of the deceased had five slip knots, and the sheet was very tightly twisted.
6.2.3 The feet of the deceased were at least two feet (24 inches) from the ground.
6.2.4 The head of the deceased appeared to be on a very close proximity to the ceiling of the cell.
6.2.5 There was no chair, stool or any other item observable in the photograph.

6.3. During the Royal Commission Hearing 22 photographs were tendered into the evidence during the evidence of Prison Office I.W. Birbeck on the 30th March, 1989. Those 22 photographs were identified as Exhibit NT/7/71. The tender of the 22 photographs can be seen at page 544 of the Transcript of the Royal Commission Hearings. Of the total of the 22 photographs 2 were seen to be photographs of the deceased hanging in his cell.

6.4 During August 1993 Letty Scott together with another attended at the office of her then solicitor, Mr Paterson of the firm Stockley and Company in Brisbane. At that meeting Letty Scott was shown copies (but original photographs) of Exhibit NT/7/71. We are instructed that the photographs showing the body of the deceased hanging by his neck in his prison cell on the 5th July, 1985 were quite different in most respects from those photos which Letty Scott and her daughters had seen during the meeting in Darwin in March 1989. The
differences were as follows:
6.4.1. The sheet around the neck of the deceased was patterned with trains and boats and planes.
6.4.2. The body was hanging some observable distance from the ceiling of the cell.
6.4.3. The feet of the deceased were situated one or two inches only away from the floor (in the copy photograph they appear to be touching the floor).
6.4.4. There was near the floor some sort of elevated platform which appears to be a stool.
6.4.5. There was one knot only in the sheet around the neck of the hanging body of the deceased.

6.5 Since Letty Scott observed these photographs at the office of her Solicitor she has developed a justifiable concern and even conviction that the true circumstances of the handling of the deceased has not been explained. Certainly, on one view of it the body was hanging, or found to be hanging, on two separate occasions in the cell. But the Royal Commission Inquiry did not elicit any evidence whatsoever that the body of the deceased was rehung after his body was found hanging in the cell. The evidence, so far as it is relevant, is that Prison Officers Lawson and Robertson were instructed and did release the body of the deceased from its hanging position and lay it on the bed after the body had been photographed by Prison Officer Birbeck.
6.6 Attached to this Submission are copies of the original photographs being copies of Exhibit NT/7/71 referred to herein.

6.7 There was never any explanation of the appearance of the hanging body of the deceased in photographs seen by Letty Scott and her family in Darwin and those produced to her through her solicitors in Brisbane.
6.8 This aspect of inquiry alone raises, in our respectful submission sufficient doubt for the purpose of instituting and undertaking some inquiry on this aspect.

6.9. Rodney Lewis, Solicitor, has spoken at some length to Geoffrey Barbaro concerning this matter but Geoffrey Barbaro is unable to agree that the photographs which were tendered into evidence at the Royal Commission Hearing (NT/7/71) are, insofar as they show the hanging body of the deceased different from the photographs where he showed Letty Scott and her family in Darwin during the Royal Commission Hearing. The lack of any satisfactory explanation for the differences adds, in our submission, to the need for a search for a proper explanation.

6.10 Another matter involving Mr Barbaro arises from information received by Mr Rodney Lewis from Mr Robert Cavanagh, now senior lecturer in the Faculty of Law at the University of Newcastle, and formerly counsel to Mrs Scott. He has advised of a conversation he had with Mr Barbaro and after that conversation telling Mrs Scott—

"Barbaro just told me that he did show you the polaroid photographs at the beginning of the Royal Commission Inquiry and he says those photographs are different from the Territory Police photographs."
Mr Cavanagh also advises that:—"I do recall discussing with Mr Barbaro the issue of Mr Scott being hung twice and recall Barbaro being concerned that that may have happened."

6.11 Any inquiry would, in our submission, seek to locate the originals of the polaroid photographs which were taken by Chief Prison Officer Birbeck. Inquires have been made continually over the years by Mrs Scott as to the whereabouts of the polaroid photographs. Most recently, a request has been made and acted upon by your department to search the records held of this matter. A thorough search of all the records was made in August 1993 without success. However, the file of the Coronial Inquest had already been returned to the Coroner's Office in Darwin on 20 April 1993. A recent written enquiry of that office has produced the written response by the Coroner's Clerk, Mr Arkinstall, that the file was indeed returned to the Office of the Coroner in April 1993 but "does not contain the two original polaroid photographs. . . "
7. The Observations of Jeffrey Bindai

7.1 One of the exhibits tendered during the course of the Royal Commission Inquiry was a Statement of J. Bindai and identified with Exhibit Marking NT/7/101. We have undertaken at the Doon Doon Station via Kunnunurra in Western Australia specific inquiries as to the circumstances of the taking of the Statement by Counsel assisting the Royal Commission with Mr Bindai on the 4th day of April, 1989. It is sufficient for the purposes of this submission to indicate that Mr Bindai now claims that the account put into evidence is only a partial statement of what he told the representatives of the Royal Commission and does not contain the whole account of what he said.
7.2 Mr Bindai has much of significance to provide as to those events at the time of the death of the deceased. Specifically they are these matters:
LEWIS 3
7.2.1. Mr Bindai was at the Darwin Gaol as a prisoner for a period of about two months before the 5th July, 1985, the day on which the deceased was found hanging in his cell.
7.2.2. Mr Bindai occupied a cell in C Block directly opposite from the cell occupied, at the time of his death, by the deceased.

7.2.3. On the evening before the 5th July, 1985 Bindai was placed in his cell at about 8 o'clock and much later that evening he heard a sound, looked out of his cell and saw four Prison Officers, carrying batons, enter the cell of the deceased. According to Mr Bindai he heard Scott calling out for help and he heard sounds coming from the cell.
7.2.4. Mr Bindai claims that other prisoners adjacent to the cell of the deceased shouted out and made comments concerning what was then taking place inside the cell of the deceased.

7.2.5. Mr Bindai claims at some point during the time that the Prison Officers were in the cell of the deceased, one of them came out and made a threat to Mr Bindai before returning to the others in the cell of the deceased.
7.2.6. Mr Bindai claims that the deceased was further assaulted by the Prison Officers inside his own cell.
7.2.7. Mr Bindai claims that the Prison Officers, after being in the cell for some time left it and walked away.
7.2.8. Rodney Lewis has recently interviewed Mr Bindai at his home in Western Australia and has confirmed again the substance of his story.
8. The Observations of Laurie Percy

8.1 During an interview which Rodney Lewis had with Mr Laurie Percy at Darwin recently he indicated that on the morning Mr Scott's body was found in the cell he was asked to go in and clean up cell. In the course of cleaning of the cell he saw blood on the sheet, pillow and on the floor of the cell. He also found blood on a ball of paper underneath the toilet.
Issues:

A. The amount of blood which Percy now says he saw in the cell is in stark contrast to the refer ence to blood in his original statement. At all events, even the reference in his original statement to blood was not subject of any enquiry or discussion before the Royal Commission.
9. The Observations of Geoffrey Moreen
9.1 Geoffrey Moreen is the brother of Laurie Percy and both were in cells opposite that of the deceased on the night and morning in question.

9.2 Mr Moreen, in a recent conversation with Rodney Lewis in Darwin, made a statement which included the following: "I remember hearing in the night Kelly called out:‐ "Somebody help me" but I thought I was dreaming and I didn't do anything.".
9.3 The reference to "Kelly" is a reference to the deceased. Apparently Mr Scott was also known by that name at least to Mr Moreen.
9.4 Mr Moreen also states that on the following morning he saw Laurie Percy and Geoffrey Bindai carrying the mattress from the cell in the course of cleaning it. He says he saw blood on the mattress.
Issues:
A: Mr Moreen by his statement appears to support and corroborate the claim that the deceased called out during the night and also that there was blood observable on the mattress.
10. Alternative scenario
10.1 Prisoner returns to cell early.
10.2 Four prison officers enter the cell during the night, with batons; Prisoner heard to cry for help.
10.3 Prisoner is murdered either in the course of, or before being hung from the grill in the cell.

10.4 Upon entry shortly after daylight the next morning, P.O. Birbeck takes two polaroid photographs of the Prisoner hanging from the grill in the ceiling, depicting the Prisoner hanging and with his head close the ceiling, feet some distance from the floor, with a plain sheet having a tightly twisted noose with several slip knots.

10.5 Prisoner is then taken down whether cut down or untied and then rehung with a different sheet, with a single slip knot, with feet apparently touching the floor and head at a distance which can be calculated to be not less than about 80 cms from the ceiling, having regard to the deceased's known height and the height of the ceiling.
10.6 The Police photographer, Constable Nieman, arrives.

10.7 Police photographer takes further photographs of the body hanging from the ceiling, later processed in such a way as to represent copies of polaroid photographs and tendered in evidence before the Royal Commission as copies of the two polaroid photographs which P.O. Birbeck took when he first entered the cell.
10.8 Prisoner is then taken down and placed on the bed where further photographs are taken.
10.9 The body is removed from the cell and Laurie Percy and Geoffrey Bindai are ordered to clean up the cell. In the course of doing so, Percy and Bindai report seeing blood.
11. Other Matters
11.1 There are in addition to the issues raised above, other matters which are of the gravest concern to Mrs Scott. They are upon our instructions as follows:‐

11.2 The bed sheets depicted in the photographs of the deceased have a pattern of trains, boats and planes. Not only does this not record with her recollection of the plain white sheet in the photograph she saw in Darwin but there is the real question of whether they were at that time regulation prison issue.
11.3 The same question arises from the clothing of the deceased as depicted in the photographs and whether or not that was at that time regulation prison issue.
Both of these issues have been sources of great anxiety and should be settled by proper evidence. Neither was raised at the inquest or at the RCIADC.

11.4 Mrs Scott remains unconvinced that a person of the height and build of the deceased could have reached the grate in bare feet in order to tie and twist the sheet by which he was hanged. A description of the knot and sheet was produced by PO Robertson, in a statement taken on 8 March 1989 for the RCIADC (p5).
11.5 Only a full and careful reconstruction and re‐enactment of the event will resolve Mrs Scott's anxiety. She is not satisfied that the visit to the cell by RC JOHNSTON accomplished that purpose.

11.6 Mrs Scott had a telephone conversation with PO Bowden (then retired) on 7th October, 1994. During that conversation Mrs Scott's instructions are that the following exchange took place:‐ "Your husband didn't die of strangulation like Dr Lee put down, he died of a broken neck."
11.7 The notion that the deceased died of a broken neck did not figure at all in any of the evidence given at the Inquest or at the RCIADC. It is a serious issue and on which needs to be pursued.

11.8 The photograph of the deceased taken full rear view hanging shows his feet without any sign of drooping. In other words they appear to be on the ground. This seems to Mrs Scott a curious way in which someone might hang themselves, with feet on the ground.

Taken another way, the evidence from PO ROBERTSON is that the deceased's feet were about 2 inches off the ground. The photograph adverted to shows no drooping of the feet, yet the photograph of the body on the bed shows the feet with a distinct droop. This contradiction further confirms that the feet were touching the ground.

11.9 The photograph taken of the upper torso from the right appears to show a mark or possible wheal and faintly but apparently extending around the mid neck region. The absence of proper illumination in this and other photographs would demonstrate poor forensic work at best and at worst the potential for concealment.
11.10 The photo last mentioned should be the subject of further detailed forensic analysis.
11.11 There was no evidence given of marks on the neck of the kind apparent on the photograph referred to in 10.9 by any of the PO's or by the forensic pathologist, Dr Lee.

11.12 It is of significance and in our submission a serious lapse of duty of the RCIADC that the inquiry into the death of the deceased began with the tendentious assumption that there was no culpability on the part of the prison officers in the incident. Such an assumption, even though with the agreement apparently of all parties, predicated an outcome which, with the benefit of having the matters now available as further evidence and debate upon the issues put in this submission, was simply not warranted if a proper and thorough forensic inquiry was undertaken.

11.13 In his Reasons for Findings, RC Johnston found (p.16) that when the deceased came before the Magistrate's Court at the end of May 1985 he was remanded in custody for a period ". . . in fact, longer than is permitted, in the absence of consent, pursuant to the relevant Northern Territory legislation." Since there was, according to the Royal Commissioner, no knowledge of the instructions of the defendant (deceased) he has concluded, without the benefit of evidence on this point, that the deceased was lawfully in custody. This will be the subject of vigorous examination at the Inquiry in support of which this submission is made.
